processed.result:
A day has $n$ hours.  There are $a_i$ people in the $i$-th timezone who want to participate in a one-hour online contest.  Each person will participate if and only if the contest starts no earlier than $s$ hours and ends no later than $f$ hours local time.  

Find the starting time (in the first timezone) that maximizes the number of participants. 

Input:

* The first line contains $n$ (2 ≤ $n$ ≤ 100,000) - the number of hours in a day.
* The second line contains $n$ space-separated integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$ (1 ≤ $a_i$ ≤ 10,000) - the number of people in each timezone.
* The third line contains two space-separated integers $s$ and $f$ (1 ≤ $s$ < $f$ ≤ $n$) - the start and end times of the contest.

Output:

* Output a single integer - the starting time of the contest (in the first timezone) that maximizes the number of participants. If there are multiple solutions, output the smallest one.

You are given a number of time zones and the number of people who want to participate in a contest in each time zone.  The contest must start at a time that is a whole number of hours and end an hour later. Find the starting time that maximizes the number of participants.
